lead_paragraph: The seemingly random killings last week in Burkina Faso, Indonesia, Iraq and Turkey highlighted the strategy of militants determined to sow fear in disparate corners of the world.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Victor Homola, Laura Fauss, Katarina Johannsen, Dionne Searcey, Caroline Chauvet, Aurelien Breeden, Lilia Blaise, Ian Austen, Dan Bilefsky, Joe Cochrane, Kevin Dougherty, Raphael Minder and Sarah Barclay.

headline.print_headline: Four Attacks, One Global Refrain: Why Them?
headline.main: Week of Attacks, Scores of Civilian Deaths and a Question: Why Them?

snippet: The seemingly random killings last week in Burkina Faso, Indonesia, Iraq and Turkey highlighted the strategy of militants determined to sow fear in disparate corners of the world.
abstract: Series of attacks by Islamic extremists that apparently targeted victims at random and killed scores of people in Iraq, Burkina Faso, Indonesia and Turkey have left loved ones in state of incomprehension; seemingly uncoordinated attacks appear to be part of international terror campaign with both Al Qaeda and Islamic State playing key roles.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
